text: Good morning, today is Wednesday, April 12th.

I'm Korva Coleman, from NPR News, 
and here are today's top stories:

President Biden will deliver remarks later 
today at Ulster University in Belfast,
Northern Ireland. As NPR's Tamara Keith reports,

Biden is there to commemorate the 25th 
anniversary of the Good Friday accords:

"The Good Friday Agreement brokered by the 
U.S. ended decades of violence in Northern

Ireland and created a power-sharing government, 
but Brexit has put strain on the agreement,

and the National Assembly is non-functional. 
National Security Council spokesman John

Kirby previewed Biden's remarks on Air Force 
One: 'The message is really congratulations

on this anniversary and a, a focus on trade and 
economics and improving that across the board.'

Kirby said Biden will engage with representatives 
of all five major political parties in

Northern Ireland — but individually not all 
together. Tamara Keith, NPR News, Belfast."

For the first time, the federal government 
has declared a synthetic drug cocktail an

"emergent threat" to public health in the 
U.S. The tranquilizer xylazine is used by

veterinarians. It's often called "tranq." 
White House officials say it's being mixed

with the opioid fentanyl and is showing up in 
most of the street drug supply in the U.S. It's

contributing to a surge in deaths. Officials say 
fatalities have increased tenfold in the South.

The city of Louisville has released body camera 
footage of the deadly shooting at a downtown

bank on Monday. Five people were killed and more 
than half a dozen others were wounded. Louisville

Deputy Police Chief Paul Humphrey lauded the 
courage of the responding officers as shown

in the recording: "You can see the tension 
in that video. You can understand the stress

that those officers are going through. (The) 
response wasn't perfect, but it was exactly the

response we needed." A Louisville officer 
shot and killed the gunman at the scene.

The White House has released its 
emergency drought plan to save the

nation's two largest reservoirs — they're 
in danger of dropping below levels that can

no longer generate power or deliver water 
to southwest cities and farms. NPR's Kirk

Siegler reports the decision comes amid a 
23-year mega-drought on the Colorado River:

"The Biden administration's plan would 
allow the government to force large,

mandatory water cuts in Nevada, Arizona 
and California — even among water users

who hold senior rights to take all they're 
entitled to from the shrinking Colorado River.

Such an extraordinary action would likely 
face lawsuits, but Bureau of Reclamation

commissioner Camille Touton says there has to be 
compromise due to the drought: 'Fundamentally,

it is one community comprised of 40 million 
people and landscapes that need us to get this

right.' This federal plan comes as the seven 
states that rely on the Colorado River have

so far failed to come up with their own voluntary 
agreement to cut water. Kirk Ziegler, NPR News."
This is NPR.
